INTEL, NSF PONY UP $150 MILLION FOR STEM EDUCATION: Chipmaker Intel and the National Science Foundation will today announce a total investment of $150 million over the next decade into science, technology and engineering education and research programs related to semiconductors, with a focus on two-year community colleges.

— GOP leadership steps in: A senior House Republican aide, who requested anonymity in order to discuss intra-caucus disagreements, called the notion that the House GOP is uninterested in antitrust as it relates to the tech industry “completely inaccurate.”
“Today’s productive conversation covered multiple priorities, including antitrust, as well as Section 230 and protecting children’s safety online,” the aide said, adding that the task force’s work is “not yet complete” and will be shaped by member feedback.

“During the past year the [FCC] has made it a priority to increase trust with a series of initiatives to support network security,” Rosenworcel told reporters after Thursday’s vote, rattling off initiatives such as fostering 5G Open RAN network technology (a much discussed alternative to using hardware from companies such as China’s Huawei) and revealing that the agency will “soon” be moving forward with new rules for authorizing telecom equipment.

— More Chinese companies booted: FCC commissioners voted Wednesday to revoke U.S. authorizations for yet another Chinese telecom company: Pacific Networks and its wholly owned subsidiary ComNet, which already have a very limited presence in the U.S.
They’re the latest Chinese companies that commissioners, on a bipartisan basis, have ejected from the U.S. in recent years, including China Telecom and China Unicom.
